question: No, Doctor. Thank you. Herr Salieri?
answer: What do you want?

question: I am Father Vogler. I am a Chaplain here. I thought you might like to talk to someone.
answer: About what?

question: You tried to take your life. You do remember that, don't you?
answer: So?

question: In the sight of God that is a sin.
answer: What do you want?

question: Do you understand that you have sinned? Gravely.
answer: Leave me alone.

question: I cannot leave alone a soul in pain.
answer: Do you know who I am? You never heard of me, did you?

question: That makes no difference. All men are equal in God's eyes.
answer: Are they?

question: Offer me your confession. I can offer you God's forgiveness.
answer: I do not seek forgiveness.

question: My son, there is something dreadful on your soul. Unburden it to me. I'm here only for you. Please talk to me.
answer: How well are you trained in music?

question: I know a little. I studied it in my youth.
answer: Where?

question: Here in Vienna.
answer: Then you must know this.

question: I can't say I do. What is it?
answer: I'm surprised you don't know. It was a very popular tune in its day. I wrote it. How about this? This one brought down the house when we played it first. Well?

question: I regret it is not too familiar.
answer: Can you recall no melody of mine? I was the most famous composer in Europe when you were still a boy. I wrote forty operas alone. What about this little thing?

question: Oh, I know that! That's charming! I didn't know you wrote that.
answer: I didn't. That was Mozart. Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart. You know who that is?

question: Of course. The man you accuse yourself of killing.
answer: Ah - you've heard that?

question: All Vienna has heard that.
answer: And do they believe it?

question: Is it true?
answer: Do you believe it?

question: Should I? For God's sake, my son, if you have anything to confess, do it now! Give yourself some peace! Do you hear me?
answer: He was murdered, Father! Mozart! Cruelly murdered.

question: Yes? Did you do it?
answer: He was my idol! I can't remember a time when I didn't know his name! When I was only fourteen he was already famous. Even in Legnago - the tiniest town in Italy - I knew of him. I was still playing childish games when he was playing music for kings and emperors. Even the Pope in Rome! I admit I was jealous when I heard the tales they told about him. Not of the brilliant little prodigy himself, but of his father, who had taught him everything. My father did not care for music. He wanted me only to be a merchant, like himself. As anonymous as he was. When I told how I wished I could be like Mozart, he would say, Why? Do you want to be a trained monkey? Would you like me to drag you around Europe doing tricks like a circus freak? How could I tell him what music meant to me? Even then a spray of sounded notes could make me dizzy, almost to falling. Whilst my father prayed earnestly to God to protect commerce, I would offer up secretly the proudest prayer a boy could think of. Lord, make me a great composer! Let me celebrate your glory through music - and be celebrated myself! Make me famous through the world, dear God! Make me immortal! After I die let people speak my name forever with love for what I wrote! In return I vow I will give you my chastity - my industry, my deepest humility, every hour of my life. And I will help my fellow man all I can. Amen and amen! And do you know what happened? A miracle! Suddenly he was dead. Just like that! And my life changed forever. My mother said, Go. Study music if you really want to. Off with you! And off I went as quick as I could and never saw Italy again. Of course, I knew God had arranged it all; that was obvious. One moment I was a frustrated boy in an obscure little town. The next I was here, in Vienna, city of musicians, sixteen years old and studying under Gluck! Gluck, Father. Do you know who he was? The greatest composer of his time. And he loved me! That was the wonder. He taught me everything he knew. And when I was ready, introduced me personally to the Emperor! Emperor Joseph - the musical king! Within a few years I was his court composer. Wasn't that incredible? Imperial Composer to His Majesty! Actually the man had no ear at all, but what did it matter? He adored my music, that was enough. Night after night I sat right next to the Emperor of Austria, playing duets with him, correcting the royal sight-reading. Tell me, if you had been me, wouldn't you have thought God had accepted your vow? And believe me, I honoured it. I was a model of virtue. I kept my hands off women, worked hours every day teaching students, many of them for free, sitting on endless committees to help poor musicians - work and work and work, that was all my life. And it was wonderful! Everybody liked me. I liked myself. I was the most successful musician in Vienna. And the happiest. Till he came. Mozart. One day he came to Vienna to play some of his music at the residence of his employer, the Prince-Archbishop of Salzburg. Eagerly I went there to seek him out. That night changed my life. As I went through the salon, I played a game with myself. This man had written his first concerto at the age of four; his first symphony at seven; a full-scale opera at twelve. Did it show? Is talent like that written on the face? Which one of them could he be?

question: Miaouw! Miaouw! Mouse-wouse? It's Puss-wuss, fangs-wangs. Paws-claws. Pounce-bounce!
answer: Stop it. Stop it! Stop it!

question: I am! I am! I'm stopping it - slowly. You see! Look, I've stopped. Now we are going back.
answer: No! No! No!

question: Yes! Back! Back! Listen - don't you know where you are?
answer: Where?

question: We are in the Residence of the Fartsbishop of Salzburg.
answer: Fartsbishop! Your Grace, I've got something to tell you. I want to complain about this man.

question: Go ahead, tell him. Tell them all. They won't understand you anyway.
answer: Why not?

question: Because here everything goes backwards. People walk backwards, dance backwards, sing backwards, and talk backwards.
answer: That's stupid.

question: Why? People fart backwards.
answer: Do you think that's funny?

question: Yes, I think it's brilliant. You've been doing it for years.
answer: Oh, ha, ha, ha.

question: Sra-I'm-sick! Sra-I'm sick!
answer: Yes, you are. You're very sick.

question: No, no. Say it backwards, shit-wit. Sra-I'm-sick Say it backwards!
answer: Sra-I'm-sick. Sick - kiss I'm - my Kiss my! Sra-I'm-sick - Kiss my arse!

question: Em iram! Em iram!
answer: No, I'm not playing this game.

question: No, this is serious. Say it backwards.
answer: No!

question: Just say it - you'll see. It's very serious. Em iram! Em iram!
answer: Iram - marry Em - marry me! No, no! You're a fiend. I'm not going to marry a fiend. A dirty fiend at that.

question: Ui-vol-i-tub!
answer: Tub - but i-tub - but I vol - love but I love ui - You. I love you!

question: Tish-I'm tee. What's that?
answer: What?

question: Tish-I'm-tee.
answer: Eat

question: Yes.
answer: Eat my - ah!

question: Follow me, please. The Archbishop would like a word.
answer: Certainly! Well, I think that went off remarkably well, don't you?

question: Indeed.
answer: These Viennese certainly know good music when they hear it.

question: His Grace is very angry with you.
answer: What do you mean?

question: Ah, Mozart. Why?
answer: Why what, sir?

question: Why do I have to be humiliated in front of my guests by one of my own servants?
answer: Humiliated?

question: How much provocation am I to endure from you? The more license I allow you, the more you take.
answer: If His Grace is not satisfied with me, he can dismiss me.

question: I wish you to return immediately to Salzburg. Your father is waiting for you there patiently. I will speak to you further when I come.
answer: No, Your Grace! I mean with all humility, no. I would rather you dismissed me. It's obvious I don't satisfy.

question: He's remarkable, Majesty. I heard an extraordinary serious opera of his last month. Idomeneo, King of Crete.
answer: That? A most tiresome piece. I heard it, too.

question: Tiresome?
answer: A young man trying to impress beyond his abilities. Too much spice. Too many notes.

question: Si. Ah! Here she comes. Fraulein Lorl, good morning.
answer: Good morning, sir.

question: What have you got for me today? Let me see. Ah-ha! Siena macaroons - my favourites. Give my best thanks to the baker.
answer: I will, sir.

question: Thank you. Are you well today, Fraulein Lorl?
answer: Yes, thank you, sir.

question: Good, good, good. Good morning, gentlemen. Well, what do you have for me today?
answer: Your Majesty, Herr Mozart -

question: Yes, what about him?
answer: He's here.

question: Ah-ha. Well. There it is. Good.
answer: Majesty, I hope you won't think it improper, but I have written a little March of Welcome in his honour.

question: What a charming idea. May I see?
answer: It's just a trifle, of course.

question: May I try it?
answer: Majesty.

question: Delightful, Court Composer. Would you permit me to play it as he comes in?
answer: You do me too much honour, Sire.

question: Let's have some fun. Bring in Herr Mozart, please. But slowly, slowly. I need a minute to practice.
answer: A-flat, Majesty.

question: Finally! Such an immense joy. Diletto straordinario!
answer: I know your work well, Signore. Do you know I actually composed some variations on a melody of yours?

question: Really?
answer: Mio caro Adone.

question: Ah!
answer: A funny little tune, but it yielded some good things.

question: Well, what is it about? Tell us the story.
answer: It's actually quite amusing, Majesty. It's set - the whole thing is set in a - in a -

question: Yes, where?
answer: In a Pasha's Harem, Majesty. A Seraglio.

question: No, I don't think you do. I mean watching Italian opera, all those male sopranos screeching. Stupid fat couples rolling their eyes about! That's not love - it's just rubbish. Majesty, you choose the language. It will be my task to set it to the finest music ever offered a monarch.
answer: Well, there it is. Let it be German. Ah, this is yours.

question: Keep it, Sire, if you want to. It is already here in my head.
answer: What? On one hearing only?

question: I think so, Sire, yes.
answer: Show me.

question: Bene.
answer: Maestro.

question: Good morning.
answer: Well? How do you like it? It's Turkish. My hairdresser tells me everything's going to be Turkish this year!

question: Really? What else did he tell you today? Give me some gossip.
answer: Well, I heard you met Herr Mozart.

question: Oh? News travels fast in Vienna.
answer: And he's been commissioned to write an opera. Is it true?

question: Yes.
answer: Is there a part for me?

question: No.
answer: How do you know?

question: Well even if there is, I don't think you want to get involved with this one.
answer: Why not?

question: Well, do you know where it's set, my dear?
answer: Where?

question: In a harem.
answer: What's that?

question: A brothel.
answer: Oh!

question: A Turkish brothel.
answer: Turkish? Oh, if it's Turkish, that's different. I want to be in it.

question: My dear, it will hardly enhance your reputation to be celebrated throughout Vienna as a singing prostitute for a Turk.
answer: Oh. Well perhaps you could introduce us anyway.

question: Perhaps.
answer: What does he look like?

question: You might be disappointed.
answer: Why?

question: Looks and talent don't always go together, Katherina.
answer: Looks don't concern me, Maestro. Only talent interests a woman of taste. Since you are determined, Since you are determined, Calmly, with no ferment, Welcome - every pain and woe. Bind me then - compel me! Bind me then - compel me! Hurt me. Break me! Kill me! At last I shall be freed by death!

question: Well, Herr Mozart! A good effort. Decidedly that. An excellent effort! You've shown us something quite new today.
answer: It is new, it is, isn't it, Sire?

question: Yes, indeed.
answer: And German?

question: Oh, yes. Absolutely. German. Unquestionably!
answer: So then you like it? You really like it, Your Majesty?

question: Of course I do. It's very good. Of course now and then - just now and then - it gets a touch elaborate.
answer: What do you mean, Sire?

question: Really? How delightful. May I ask when you marry?
answer: Well - Well we haven't quite received my father's consent, Your Majesty. Not entirely. Not altogether.

question: Excuse me, but how old are you?
answer: Twenty-six.

question: Katherina! I'll tell you what I'm going to do. I'm going to write another aria for you. Something even more amazing for the second act. I have to get some water. Her mother is lying on the stage.
answer: Don't bother!

question: What?
answer: Don't bother.

question: Ah, what an evening! What a wise man we have for an Emperor. Oh, my children! Now I want you to write your father exactly what His Majesty said.
answer: You should really go home now, Frau Weber. Your carriage must be waiting.

question: But aren't you taking us?
answer: I have to talk to the singers.

question: Did you know? Had you heard?
answer: What?

question: The marriage!
answer: Well, what does it matter to you?

question: Nothing! He can marry who he pleases. I don't give a damn. How was I? Tell me honestly.
answer: You were sublime.

question: What did you think of the music?
answer: Extremely clever.

question: Meaning you didn't like it.
answer: Oh - excuse me!

question: Is her mother still lying on the floor?
answer: No, she's fine.

question: No! I won't have him back.
answer: But he needs to be here in Salzburg, Your Grace. He needs me and he needs you. Your protection, your understanding.

question: Hardly.
answer: Oh sir, yes! He's about to make the worst mistake of his life. Some little Viennese slut is trying to trick him into marriage. I know my son. He is too simple to see the trap - and there is no one there who really cares for him.

question: I'm not surprised. Money seems to be more important to him than loyalty or friendship. He has sold himself to Vienna. Let Vienna look out for him.
answer: Sir -

question: Your son is an unprincipled, spoiled, conceited brat.
answer: Yes, sir, that's the truth. But don't blame him. The fault is mine. I was too indulgent with him. But not again. Never again, I promise! I implore you - let me bring him back here. I'll make him give his word to serve you faithfully.

question: And how will you make him keep it?
answer: Oh, sir, he's never disobeyed me in anything. Please, Your Grace, give him one more chance.

question: You have leave to try.
answer: Oh, Your Grace - I thank Your Grace! I thank you! My dear son. I write to you with urgent news. I am coming to Vienna. Take no further steps toward marriage until we meet. You are too gullible to see your own danger. As you honour the father who has devoted his entire life to yours, do as I bid, and await my coming.

question: Good morning, Court Composer. This is my niece, the Princess Elizabeth.
answer: Your Highness.

question: She has asked me to advise her on a suitable musical instructor. I think I've come up with an excellent idea.
answer: Oh, Your Majesty, it would be such a tremendous honour!

question: I'm thinking about Herr Mozart. What is your view?
answer: An interesting idea, Majesty. But -

question: Yes?
answer: You already commissioned an opera from Mozart.

question: And the result satisfies.
answer: Yes, of course. My concern is to protect you from any suspicion of favouritism.

question: Ah-ha. Favouritism. But I so want Mozart.
answer: I'm sure there is a way, Majesty. Some kind of a little contest. I could perhaps put together a small Committee, and I could see to it naturally that it will select according to Your Majesty's wishes.

question: You please me, Court Composer. A very clever idea.
answer: Sire.

question: What is this, Herr Chamberlain?
answer: What is what?

question: Why do I have to submit samples of my work to some stupid committee? Just to teach a sixteen-year-old girl.
answer: Because His Majesty wishes it.

question: Is the Emperor angry with me?
answer: On the contrary.

question: Then why doesn't he simply appoint me to the post?
answer: Mozart, you are not the only composer in Vienna.

question: No, but I'm the best.
answer: A little modesty would suit you better.

question: Who is on this committee?
answer: Kapellmeister Bonno, Count Orsini- Rosenberg and Court Composer Salieri.

question: Naturally, the Italians! Of course! Always the Italians!
answer: Mozart -

question: They hate my music. It terrifies them. The only sound Italians understand is banality. Tonic and dominant, tonic and dominant, from here to Resurrection! Ba-ba! Ba-ba! Ba-ba! Ba-ba! Anything else is morbid.
answer: Mozart -

question: Show them one interesting modulation and they faint. Ohime! Morbidezza! Morbidezza! Italians are musical idiots and you want them to judge my music!
answer: Look, young man, the issue is simple. If you want this post, you must submit your stuff in the same way as all your colleagues.

question: Must I? Well, I won't! I tell you straight
answer: I think you're mad! You're really mad!

question: Oh, leave me alone.
answer: One royal pupil and the whole of Vienna will come flocking. We'd be set up for life!

question: They'll come anyway. They love me here.
answer: No, they will not. I know how things work in this city.

question: Oh yes? You always know everything.
answer: Well, I'm not borrowing any more money from my mother, and that's that!

question: You borrowed money from your mother?
answer: Yes!

question: Well, don't do that again!
answer: How are we going to live, Wolfi? Do you want me to go into the streets and beg?

question: Don't be stupid.
answer: All they want to see is your work. What's wrong with that?

question: Shut up! Just shut up! I don't need them.
answer: This isn't pride. It's sheer stupidity!

question: Yes.
answer: Excuse me, sir, there is a lady who insists on talking to you.

question: Who is she?
answer: She didn't say. But she says it's urgent.

question: Excuse me, my dear.
answer: Excellency!

question: Madame. How can I help you? Frau Mozart?
answer: That's right, Your Excellency. I've come on behalf of my hus band. I'm - I'm bringing some samples of his work so he can be considered for the royal appointment.

question: How charming. But why did he not come himself?
answer: He's terribly busy, sir.

question: I understand. I will look at them, of course, the moment I can. It will be an honour. Please give him my warmest.
answer: Would it be too much trouble, sir, to ask you to look at them now? While I wait.

question: I'm afraid I'm not at leisure this very moment. Just leave them with me. I assure you they will be quite safe.
answer: I - I really cannot do that, Your Excellency. You see, he doesn't know I'm here.

question: Really?
answer: My husband is a proud man, sir. He would be furious if he knew I'd come.

question: Then he didn't send you?
answer: No, sir. This is my own idea.

question: I see.
answer: Sir, we really need this job. We're desperate. My husband spends far more than he can ever earn. I don't mean he's lazy - he's not at all - he works all day long. It's just! he's not practical. Money simply slips through his fingers, it's really ridiculous, Your Excellency. I know you help musicians. You're famous for it. Give him just this one post. We'd be forever indebted!

question: Let me offer you some refreshment. Do you know what these are? Cappezzoli di Venere. Nipples of Venus. Roman chestnuts in brandied sugar. Won't you try one? They're quite surprising.
answer: Oh! They're wonderful. Thank you very much, Your Excellency.

question: Don't keep calling me that. It puts me at such a distance. I was not born a Court Composer, you know. I'm from a small town, just like your husband. Are you sure you can't leave that music, and come back again? I have other things you might like.
answer: That's very tempting, but it's impossible, I'm afraid. Wolfi would be frantic if he found those were missing. You see, they're all originals.

question: Originals?
answer: Yes.

question: These are originals?
answer: Yes, sir. He doesn't make copies.

question: Is it no good?
answer: It is miraculous.

question: Oh yes. He's really proud of his work. So, will you help him?
answer: Tomorrow night I dine with the Emperor. One word from me and the post is his.

question: Oh, thank you, sir!
answer: Come back tonight.

question: Tonight?
answer: Alone.

question: What for?
answer: Some service deserves service in return. No?

question: What do you mean?
answer: Isn't it obvious? It's a post all Vienna seeks. If you want it for your husband, come tonight.

question: But! I'm a married woman!
answer: Then don't. It's up to you. Not to be vague, that is the price. Yes.

question: Yes, Father. Yes! So much for my vow of chastity. What did it matter? Good, patient, hard-working, chaste - what did it matter? Had goodness made me a good composer? I realized it absolutely then - that moment
answer: You cannot say that!

question: No? Was Mozart a good man?
answer: God's ways are not yours. And you are not here to question Him. Offer him the salt of penitence. He will give you back the bread of eternal life. He is all merciful. That is all you need to know.

question: All I ever wanted was to sing to Him. That's His doing, isn't it? He gave me that longing - then made me mute. Why? Tell me that. If He didn't want me to serve Him with music, why implant the desire, like a lust in my body, then deny me the talent? Go on, tell me! Speak for Him!
answer: My son, no one can speak for God.

question: Oh? I thought you did so every day. So speak now. Answer me!
answer: I do not claim to unravel the mysteries. I treasure them. As you should.

question: Show her in. Then go to bed.
answer: Well, I'm here. My husband has gone to a concert. He didn't think I would enjoy it. I do apologize for this afternoon. I behaved like a silly girl. Where shall we go?

question: What?
answer: Should we stay here? It's a charming room. I love these candlesticks. Were they here earlier? I didn't notice them I suppose I was too nervous. Wolfgang was given some candlesticks by King George in England, but they were only wood. Oh, excuse me. Let's not talk about him. What do you think of this? It's real lace. Brussels. Well, it's much too good for every day. I keep saying to Wolfi, don't be so extravagant. Presents are lovely, but we can't afford them. It doesn't do any good. The more I tell him, the more he spends. Oh, excuse me! There I go again. Do you still want to look at this? Or don't we need to bother anymore? I imagine we don't, really.

question: Go! Go! Go! Show this woman out!
answer: You shit! You shit! You rotten shit! What are you staring at?

question: Stanzi! Stanzi! Stanzi-Manzi! Sssh!
answer: Stanzi-Manzi-Banzi-Wanzi!

question: Sssh! Stay here.
answer: Sssh! You're dishgrashful!

question: Stanzi? How's my mouse? Mouse-wouse? I'm back - puss-wuss is back! Stanzi! What's the matter? What is it? Stanzi! Stop it now. Stop it. I've brought some friends to meet you. They're next door waiting. Do we have anything to eat? They're all starving.
answer: Tell them to go away. I don't want to see anybody.

question: What's the matter with you?
answer: Tell them to go!

question: Sssh. What is it? Tell me.
answer: No!

question: Yes!
answer: I love you! I love you! I love you. Please stay with me. I'm frightened.

question: I don't think you understand me, Court Composer.
answer: Majesty, I did. Believe me, it was a most agonizing. decision. But finally, I simply could not recommend Herr Mozart.

question: Why not?
answer: Well, Sire, I made some inquiries in a routine way. I was curious to know why he had so few pupils. It is rather alarming.

question: Oh?
answer: Majesty, I don't like to talk against a fellow musician.

question: Of course not.
answer: I have to tell you, Mozart is not entirely to be trusted alone with young ladies.

question: Really?
answer: As a matter of fact, one of my own pupils - a very young singer - told me she was - er - well!

question: Yes?
answer: Molested, Majesty. Twice, in the course of the same lesson.

question: Come with me. And stay in the room. Herr Mozart, what brings you here?
answer: Your Excellency, you requested some specimens of my work. Here they are. I don't have to tell you how much I need your help. I truly appreciate your looking at these. I have pressures on me - financial pressures. As you know, I'm a married man now.

question: So you are. How is your pretty wife?
answer: She is well. She is - well, actually, I'm about to become a father! She only told me last night. You are the first to know.

question: I'm flattered. And congratulations to you, of course.
answer: So you see, this post is very important to me right now.

question: Why didn't you come to me yesterday, Mozart? This is a most painful situation. Yesterday I could have helped you. Today, I can't.
answer: Why? Here is the music. It's here. I am submitting it humbly. Isn't that what you wanted?

question: I have just come from the palace. The post has been filled.
answer: Filled? That's impossible! They haven't even seen my work. I need this post. Please, can't you help me? Please!

question: My dear Mozart, there is no one in the world I would rather help, but now it is too late.
answer: Whom did they choose?

question: Herr Sommer.
answer: Sommer? Herr Sommer? But the man's a fool! He's a total mediocrity.

question: No, no, no
answer: But I can't lose this post, I simply can't! Excellency, please. Let's go to the palace, and you can explain to the Emperor that Herr Sommer is an awful choice. He could actually do musical harm to the Princess!

question: An implausible idea. Between you and me, no one in the world could do musical harm to the Princess Elizabeth.
answer: Look, I must have pupils. Without pupils I can't manage.

question: You don't mean to tell me you are living in poverty?
answer: No, but I'm broke. I'm always broke. I don't know why.

question: It has been said, my friend, that you are inclined to live somewhat above your means.
answer: How can anyone say that? We have no cook, no maid. We have no footman. Nothing at all!

question: How is that possible? You give concerts, don't you? I hear they are quite successful.
answer: They're stupendously successful. You can't get a seat. The only problem is none will hire me. They all want to hear me play, but they won't let me teach their daughters. As if I was some kind of fiend. I'm not a fiend!

question: Of course not.
answer: Do you have a daughter?

question: I'm afraid not.
answer: Well, could you lend me some money till you have one? Then I'll teach her for free. That's a promise. Oh, I'm sorry. I'm being silly. Papa's right - I should put a padlock on my mouth. Seriously, is there any chance you could manage a loan? Only for six months, eight at most. After that I'll be the richest man in Vienna. I'll pay you back double. Anything. Name your terms. I'm not joking. I'm working on something that's going to explode like a bomb all over Europe!

question: Ah, how exciting! Tell me more.
answer: I'd better not. It's a bit of a secret.

question: Come, come, Mozart; I'm interested. Truly.
answer: Actually, it's a big secret. Oh, this is delicious! What is it?

question: Cream cheese mixed with granulated sugar and suffused with rum. Crema al Mascarpone.
answer: Ah. Italian?

question: Forgive me. We all have patriotic feelings of some kind.
answer: Two thousand, two hundred florins is all I need A hundred? Fifty?

question: What exactly are you working on?
answer: I can't say. Really

question: Quiet! Quiet! Quiet! Down there, damn you. Welcome to you. Pay no attention, they're impossible. Stop it, you willful things! Come this way. Just ignore them. They're perfectly harmless, just willful. I treat them just like my own children.
answer: And which one of them do you want me to teach?

question: What? Ha-ha! That's funny - I like it. Which one, eh? You're a funny fellow. Hannah! Come this way. Hannah! You won't be teaching this one either. She's my wife.
answer: Madame.

question: Of course, it's him. Who do you think it is?
answer: I've heard about you for ages! I thought you must be an old man.

question: Gertrude!
answer: It's such an honour for us to have you here, Herr Mozart. And for Gertrude.

question: People who know say the girl's got talent. You must judge for yourself. If you think she stinks, say so.
answer: Michael, please! I'm sure you will find her most willing, Herr Mozart. She's really very excited. She's been preparing all morning.

question: Well, yes! on the whole. I suppose. How long have you been playing, Fraulein?
answer: Just one year.

question: Who was your teacher?
answer: I was. But she quite outgrew the little I could show her.

question: Papa! PAPA! Why are you here?
answer: Am I not welcome?

question: Of course, welcome! Welcome ten thousand times. Papa! my Papa!
answer: You're very thin. Does she not feed you, this wife of yours?

question: Feed? Well, of course she feeds me. She stuffs me like a goose all day long. She's the best cook in the world. I mean, since Mama. Just wait, you'll see.
answer: Is she not here?

question: I don't know. Stanzi? Stanzi!
answer: Do you always live like this?

question: Oh, yes. Oh, I mean no - not exactly like this. I mean today - just today, Stanzi - I remember now. She had to go - yes! She had to help her mother. Yes, she's like that. Her mother's a very sweet woman, you'll see. Oh! I didn't know you were home. Stanzi, this is my father. We'll wait, we'll wait. Why don't you get up now, darling? She's very tired, poor creature. You know me
answer: Don't you have a maid?

question: Oh we could, if we wanted to, but Stanzi won't hear of it. She wants to do everything herself.
answer: How is your financial situation?

question: It couldn't be better.
answer: That's not what I hear.

question: What do you mean? It's wonderful. Really, it's - it's marvelous! People love me here.
answer: They say you're in debt.

question: Who? Who says that? Now that's a malicious lie!
answer: How many pupils do you have?

question: Pupils?
answer: Yes.

question: Yes.
answer: How many?

question: I don't know. It's not important. I mean, I don't want pupils. They get in the way. I've got to have time for composition.
answer: Composition doesn't pay. You know that.

question: This one will.
answer: What's that?

question: Oh, let's not talk about it.
answer: Why not?

question: It's a secret.
answer: You don't have secrets from me.

question: Didn't I? I thought I did. I'm sure I did.
answer: May I offer you some tea, Herr Mozart?

question: Tea? Who wants tea? Let's go out! This calls for a feast. You don't want tea, Papa. Let's go dancing. Papa loves parties, don't you?
answer: Wolfi!

question: What? How can you be so boring? Tea!
answer: Wolfi, I think your father's tired. I'll cook us something here.

question: But my penalty. I've got to have a penalty.
answer: I've got a good one. I've got the perfect one for you. Come over here. Now, I want you to play our tune - sitting backwards.

question: Oh, that's really too easy. Any child can do that.
answer: And a fugue in the manner of Sebastian Bach.

question: Wolfi! Wolfgang!
answer: What is it?

question: There's a young girl to see you.
answer: What does she want?

question: I don't know.
answer: Well, ask her!

question: She won't talk to me. She says she has to speak to you.
answer: Oh, damn! Yes?

question: Oh, damn! Yes?
answer: Are you Herr Mozart?

question: That's right.
answer: My name is Lorl, sir. I'm a maidservant. I was asked to come here and offer my services to you.

question: What?
answer: They'll be paid for by a great admirer or yours who wishes to remain anon - anonymous.

question: I never saw this girl in my life. Is this a kind of joke?
answer: Not at all, sir. And I was told to wait for an answer.

question: Young woman, this won't do at all. My son can't possibly accept such an offer, no matter how generous, unless he knows who is behind it.
answer: But I really can't tell you, sir.

question: Never mind. You won't have to do anything for me ever again. I'm leaving!
answer: Papa!

question: Don't worry, I'm not staying here to be a burden.
answer: No one calls you that.

question: She does. She says I sleep all day.
answer: And so you do! The only time you come out is to eat.

question: And what do you expect? Who wants to walk out into a mess like this every day?
answer: Oh, now I'm a bad housekeeper!

question: So you are! The place is a pigsty all the time.
answer: Do you hear him? Do you? When can you start?

question: They're out every night, sir. Till all hours. Oh, thank you, sir.
answer: Do any pupils come to the house?

question: Not that I've seen.
answer: Then how does he pay for all this? Does he work at all?

question: Oh, yes, sir, all day long. He never leaves the house until evening. He just sits there, writing and writing. He doesn't even eat.
answer: Really? What is it he's writing?

question: Oh, I wouldn't know that, sir.
answer: Of course not. You're a good girl. You're very kind to do this. Next time you're sure they'll be out of the house, let me know, will you?

question: Oh, thank you, sir! I think I've found out about the money, sir.
answer: Yes what?

question: He kept seven snuff boxes in here. I could swear they were all gold. And now look there's only one left. And inside, sir, look - I counted them - tickets from the pawnshop. Six of them.
answer: Where does he work?

question: Ah! By all means.
answer: Your Majesty.

question: Good evening. We have met before, Herr Mozart.
answer: That's right, Your Majesty. Twenty years ago. No, twenty-two! twenty- three! And I remember word for word what you said to me. You said - you said --

question: Bravo?
answer: No! Yes, 'bravo,' of course 'bravo'! Everybody always says 'bravo' when Wolfi plays. Like the King of England. When we played for the King of England, he got up at the end and said, 'Bravo! Bravo! Bravo!' three times. Three bravo's. And the Pope four! Four bravo's from the Holy Father, and one 'bellissimo.'

question: And that's not all. He has chosen for his subject, Figaro. The Marriage of Figaro.
answer: You mean that play?

question: Exactly.
answer: He's setting that play to music?

question: Yes.
answer: You must be mad.

question: You must be mad.
answer: What is this Marriage of Figaro?

question: It's a French play, Kapellmeister. It has been banned by the Emperor.
answer: Hah!

question: I know we banned this play, but frankly I can't remember why. Can you refresh my memory, Herr Director?
answer: For the same reason, Herr Chamberlain, that it was banned in France.

question: Oh yes, yes. And that was?
answer: Well, the play makes a hero out of a valet. He outwits his noble master and exposes him as a lecher. Do you see the implications? This would be, in a grander situation, as if a Chamberlain were to expose an Emperor.

question: Sit down, gentlemen, please. Mozart, are you aware I have declared the French play of Figaro unsuitable for our theatre?
answer: Yes, Sire.

question: Yet we hear you are making an opera from it. Is this true?
answer: Who told you this, Majesty?

question: It is not your place to ask questions. Is it true?
answer: Well, yes, I admit it is.

question: Would you tell me why?
answer: Well, Majesty, it is only a comedy.

question: But, Your Majesty -
answer: Mozart, I am a tolerant man. I do not censor things lightly. When I do, I have good reason. Figaro is a bad play. It stirs up hatred between the classes. In France it has caused nothing but bitterness. My own dear sister Antoinette writes me that she is beginning to be frightened of her own people. I do not wish to see the same fears starting here.

question: Sire, I swear to Your Majesty, there's nothing like that in the story. I have taken out everything that could give offense. I hate politics.
answer: I think you are rather innocent, my friend. In these dangerous times I cannot afford to provoke our nobles or our people simply over a theatre piece.

question: But, Majesty, this is just a frolic. It's a piece about love.
answer: Ah, love again.

question: But it's new, it's entirely new. It's so new, people will go mad for it. For example, I have a scene in the second act - it starts as a duet, just a man and wife quarreling. Suddenly the wife's scheming little maid comes in unexpectedly - a very funny situation. Duet turns into trio. Then the husband's equally screaming valet comes in. Trio turns into quartet. Then a stupid old gardener - quartet becomes quintet, and so on. On and on, sextet, septet, octet! How long do you think I can sustain that?
answer: I have no idea.

question: Guess! Guess, Majesty. Imagine the longest time such a thing could last, then double it.
answer: Well, six or seven minutes! maybe eight!

question: Twenty, sire! How about twenty? Twenty minutes of continuous music. No recitatives.
answer: Mozart -

question: Sire, only opera can do this. In a play, if more than one person speaks at the same time, it's just noise. No one can understand a word. But with music, with music you can have twenty individuals all talking at once, and it's not noise - it's a perfect harmony. Isn't that marvelous?
answer: Mozart, music is not the issue here. No one doubts your talent. It is your judgment of literature that's in question. Even with the politics taken out, this thing would still remain a vulgar farce. Why waste your spirit on such rubbish? Surely you can choose more elevated themes?

question: Elevated? What does that mean? Elevated! The only thing a man should elevate is - oh, excuse me. I'm sorry. I'm stupid. But I am fed up to the teeth with elevated things! Old dead legends! How can we go on forever writing about gods and legends?
answer: Because they do. They go on forever - at least what they represent. The eternal in us, not the ephemeral. Opera is here to ennoble us. You and me, just as much as His Majesty.

question: Well, gentlemen, so be it. In that case I think we should help Mozart all we can and do our best to protect him against the Emperor's anger.
answer: What anger?

question: About the ballet.
answer: Ballet? What ballet?

question: Excuse me - didn't His Majesty specifically forbid ballet in his opera?
answer: Yes, absolutely. Is there a ballet in Figaro?

question: Yes, in the third act.
answer: Mozart! Herr Mozart, may I have a word with you please. Right away.

question: Mozart! Herr Mozart, may I have a word with you please. Right away.
answer: Certainly, Herr Director. Five minutes, please!

question: Did you not know that His Majesty has expressly forbidden ballet in his operas?
answer: Yes, but this is not a ballet. This is a dance at Figaro's wedding.

question: Exactly. A dance.
answer: But surely the Emperor didn't mean to prohibit dancing when it's part of the story.

question: It is dangerous for you to interpret His Majesty's edicts. Give me your score, please. Thank you.
answer: What are you doing? What are you doing, Herr Director?

question: Please! Please. I've no one else to turn to. Please!
answer: Wolfgang, what is it? Sta calmo, per favore. What's the matter?

question: It's unbelievable! The Director has actually ripped out a huge section of my music. Pages of it.
answer: Really? Why?

question: I don't know. They say I've got to re-write the opera, but it's perfect as it is. I can't rewrite what's perfect. Can't you talk to him?
answer: Why bother with Orsini-Rosenberg? He's obviously no friend of yours.

question: Oh, I could kill him! I mean really kill him. I actually threw the entire opera on the fire, he made me so angry!
answer: You burned the score?

question: Oh no! My wife took it out in time.
answer: How fortunate.

question: It's not fair that a man like that has power over our work.
answer: But there are those who have power over him. I think I'll take this up with the Emperor.

question: Oh, Excellency, would you?
answer: With all my heart, Mozart.

question: Thank you! Oh, thank you.
answer: No, no, no, Herr Mozart, please. It's not a holy relic.

question: Nine performances! Nine! That's all it's had - and withdrawn.
answer: I know; it's outrageous. Still, if the public doesn't like one's work one has to accept the fact gracefully.

question: But what is it they don't like?
answer: Well, I can speak for the Emperor. You made too many demands on the royal ear. The poor man can't concentrate for more than an hour and you gave him four.

question: What did you think of it yourself? Did you like it at all?
answer: I think it's marvelous. Truly.

question: It's the best opera yet written. I know it! Why didn't they come?
answer: I think you overestimate our dear Viennese, my friend. Do you know you didn't even give them a good bang at the end of songs so they knew when to clap?

question: I know, I know. Perhaps you should give me some lessons in that.
answer: I wouldn't presume. All the same, if it wouldn't be imposing, I would like you to see my new piece. It would be a tremendous honour for me.

question: Oh no, the honour would be all mine.
answer: Grazie, mio caro, Wolfgang!

question: Mozart. It was good of you to come.
answer: How could I not?

question: Did my work please you?
answer: How could it not, Excellency?

question: Yes?
answer: I never knew that music like that was possible.

question: You flatter me.
answer: Oh no! One hears such sounds and what can one say, but - Salieri! Oh. Everybody's here! We've got guests. Good. I've brought some more. We'll have a little party. Come in. Come in. You know Herr Schikaneder? This is! a very nice girl.

question: Oh no! One hears such sounds and what can one say, but - Salieri! Oh. Everybody's here! We've got guests. Good. I've brought some more. We'll have a little party. Come in. Come in. You know Herr Schikaneder? This is! a very nice girl.
answer: Wolfi.

question: Yes, my love?
answer: These gentlemen are from Salzburg.

question: Salzburg. We were just talking about Salzburg. If you've come from my friend the Fartsbishop, you've arrived at just the right moment. Because I've got good news for him. I'm done with Vienna. It's over, finished, done with! Done with! Done with!
answer: Wolfi! Your father is dead.

question: What?
answer: Your father is dead.

question: Who is it? C-c-c-come in!
answer: Don Giovannnnnnnnnni! Down! Down! I'm here! I'm here! Don Giovannnnnnnni!

question: Who the devil are you? What do you want?
answer: I've come to dinnnnnner!

question: Dinner? How dare you? I am a nobleman. I only dine with people of my own height.
answer: Are you drunk? You invited me. And my horse. Here he is. Ottavio! Whoa! Whoa! Stop it!

question: Well, how do you like that?
answer: Wonderful! He liked the monkey, didn't you?

question: Yes, well, it's all good fun.
answer: I liked the horse.

question: Isn't he marvelous? He cost me a bundle, that horse, but he's worth it. I tell you, if you'd played Don Giovanni here it would have been a great success. I'm not joking. These people aren't fools. You could do something marvelous for them.
answer: I'd like to try them someday. I'm not sure I'd be much good at it.

question: 'Course you would. You belong here, my boy, not the snobby Court. You could do anything you felt like here - the more fantastic the better! That's what people want, you know
answer: Animals?

question: I tell you I picked up a snake in Dresden last week - twelve foot long - folds up to six inches, just like a paper fan. It's a miracle. I'm serious. You write a proper part for me with a couple of catchy songs, I'll guarantee you'll have a triumph- de-luxe. Mind you, it'll have to be in German.
answer: German!

question: Of course! What else do you think they speak here?
answer: No, no, I love that. I'd want it to be in German. I haven't done anything in German since Seraglio.

question: You're not going to do this?
answer: Why not? Half the house!

question: When? We need money now. Either he pays now, or you don't do it.
answer: Oh, Stanzi.

question: I don't trust this man. And I didn't like what he did with your opera. It was common.
answer: Well, you liked it, didn't you? Monkey-flunki-punki.

question: Half the house! You'll never see a penny. I want it here, in my hand.
answer: Stanzi-manzi, I'll put it in your hand!

question: Herr Mozart. What a surprise. What can I do for you?
answer: Is my pupil still anxious to learn the art of music?

question: Well, your pupil is married and living in Mannheim, young man.
answer: Really? Perhaps your dear wife might care to profit from my instruction?

question: What is this, Mozart? What's the matter with you?
answer: Well. Since it appears nobody is eager to hire my services, could you favour me with a little money instead?

question: What for?
answer: If a man cannot earn, he must borrow.

question: Well, this is hardly the way to go about it.
answer: No doubt, sir. But I am endowed with talent, and you with money. If I offer mine, you should offer yours.

question: I'm sorry. No.
answer: Please. I'll give it back, I promise. Please, sir.

question: My answer is no, Mozart.
answer: Please. Please. Please. Please. Please. Please.

question: This is embarrassing, you know. You introduced Mozart to some of my friends and he's begging from practically all of them. It has to stop.
answer: I agree, Baron.

question: Can't you think of anyone who might commission some work from him? I've done my best. I got him to arrange some Bach for my Sunday concerts. He got a fee - what I could afford. Can't you think of anyone who might do something for him?
answer: No, Baron, no. I'm afraid Mozart is a lost cause. He has managed to alienate practically the whole of Vienna. He is constantly drunk. He never pays his debts. I can't think of one person to whom I dare recommend him.

question: How sad. It's tragic, isn't it? Such a talent.
answer: Indeed. Just a moment - as a matter of fact I think I do know someone who could commission a work from him. A very appropriate person to do so. Yes. Herr Mozart? I have come to commission work from you.

question: Indeed. Just a moment - as a matter of fact I think I do know someone who could commission a work from him. A very appropriate person to do so. Yes. Herr Mozart? I have come to commission work from you.
answer: What work?

question: A Mass for the dead.
answer: What dead? Who is dead?

question: A man who deserved a Requiem Mass and never got one.
answer: Who are you?

question: I am only a messenger. Do you accept? You will be paid well.
answer: How much?

question: Fifty ducats. Another fifty when I have the Mass. Do you accept?
answer: How long will you give me?

question: Wolfi? Wolfi! Who was that?
answer: No one.

question: I heard voices. What's the matter? What's that? Oh! Who gave you this? How much is it? Wolfi, who gave you this?
answer: I'm not telling you.

question: Why not?
answer: You'd think I was mad.

question: My plan was so simple, it terrified me. First I must get the Death Mass and then achieve the death.
answer: What?

question: His funeral - imagine it! The Cathedral, all Vienna sitting there. His coffin, Mozart's little coffin in the middle. And suddenly in that silence, music. A divine music bursts out over them all, a great Mass of Death
answer: Yes.

question: Am I interrupting something?
answer: Not at all.

question: Where's our friend?
answer: He's not in. But he's working on it. He said to tell you.

question: I hope so. I need it immediately. Is he happy with it? Is this it? What the devil is this? Requiem Mass? Does he think I'm in the funeral business?
answer: Leave that alone!

question: Wolfi!
answer: Put it down!

question: What is this?
answer: Put it down, I said! It's nothing for you.

question: Oh! I'm sorry! I'm sorry! What have you got for me? Is it finished?
answer: What?

question: What? The vaudeville, what'd you think?
answer: Yes.

question: Can I see it?
answer: No.

question: Why not?
answer: Because there's nothing to see.

question: Look, I asked you if we could start rehearsal next week and you said yes.
answer: Well, we can.

question: So let me see it. Where is it?
answer: Here. It's all right here, in my noodle. The rest is just scribbling. Scribbling and bibbling. Bibbling and scribbling. Would you like a drink?

question: Look, you little clown, do you know how many people I've hired for you? Do you know how many people are waiting?
answer: Leave him alone!

question: I'm paying these people. Do you realize that?
answer: He's doing his best.

question: I'm paying people just to wait for you. It's ridiculous!
answer: You know what's ridiculous? Your libretto, that's what's ridiculous. Only an idiot would ask Wolfi to work on that stuff!

question: Oh yes? And what's so intelligent about writing a Requiem?
answer: Money! Money!

question: You're mad! She's mad, Wolfi.
answer: Oh yes, and who are you? He's worked for Kings. For the Emperor. Who are you?

question: Now calm yourself. Calm. What's the matter with you?
answer: I'm leaving. I'm not working there anymore. I'm scared!

question: Why? What has happened?
answer: You don't know what it's like. Herr Mozart frightens me. He drinks all day, then takes all that medicine and it makes him worse.

question: What medicine?
answer: I don't know. He has pains.

question: Where?
answer: Here, in his stomach. They bend him right over.

question: Is he working?
answer: I'm frightened, sir. Really! When he speaks, he doesn't make any sense. You know he said he saw - he said he saw his father. And his father's dead.

question: Is he working?
answer: I suppose so. He sits there all he time, doing some silly opera.

question: Opera? Opera!
answer: Please don't ask me to go back again. I'm frightened! I'm very, very frightened.

question: Wolfi, I think you really are going mad. You work like a slave for that idiot actor who won't give you a penny and here. This is not a ghost! This is a real man who puts down real money. Why on earth don't you finish it? Give me one reason I can understand.
answer: I can't write it!

question: Why not?
answer: It's killing me.

question: No, this is really awful. You're drunk, aren't you? Be honest - tell me - you've been drinking. And I'm so stupid I stay here and listen to you! It's not fair! I worry about you all the time. I try to help you all I can and you just drink and talk nonsense and - and frighten me! It's not fair!
answer: Go back to bed.

question: Please! Let me sit here. Let me stay here with you. I promise I won't say all word. I'll just be here, so you know no one's going to hurt you. Please, please!
answer: Stanzi? Stanzi-marini-bini?

question: Here I am, my angel.
answer: What? Who the devil are you?

question: I've taken pity on you, my angel. I heard your wish.
answer: Oh. Well, thank you! How wonderful. Some people get all the luck.

question: Now you've got to promise me faithfully you'll remain true to me forever. Then you'll see how tenderly your little birdie will love you.
answer: I can't wait.

question: Well, promise then.
answer: What do you mean - now?

question: Of course now. Right away, before I get any older.
answer: Well, I don't know! I mean you're a delicious, delightful, delectable little bird, but don't you think you might be just a little tough?

question: What happened? Is it over?
answer: I'm taking you home. You're not well.

question: No, no. I have to get back. I have -
answer: Thank you. Go.

question: Papa! Papa!
answer: Come now. Where is your wife?

question: Not here! She's not well, either. She went to the Spa.
answer: You mean she's not coming back?

question: You're so good to me. Truly. Thank you.
answer: No, please.

question: I mean to come to my opera. You are the only colleague who did.
answer: I would never miss anything that you had written. You must know that.

question: This is only a vaudeville.
answer: Oh no. It is a sublime piece. The grandest operone. I tell you, you are the greatest composer known to me.

question: Do you mean that?
answer: I do.

question: I have bad fancies. I don't sleep well anymore. Then I drink too much, and think stupid things.
answer: Are you ill?

question: The doctor thinks I am. But -
answer: What?

question: I'm too young to be so sick.
answer: Shall I answer it?

question: No! No, it's him!
answer: Who?

question: The man. He's here.
answer: What man?

question: Tell him to go away. Tell him I'm still working on it. Don't let him in! Wait! Ask him if he'd give me some money now. Tell him if he would, that would help me finish it.
answer: Finish what?

question: Herr Salieri.
answer: Yes, I am looking after him.

question: Can we come in?
answer: Well, he's sleeping now. Better not.

question: But he's all right?
answer: Oh, yes. He's just exhausted. He became dizzy, that's all. We should let him rest.

question: Well, tell him we were here, won't you?
answer: Of course.

question: And say everything went wonderfully. A triumph-de-luxe - say that! Tell him the audience shouted his name a hundred times.
answer: Bene.

question: I'll call tomorrow.
answer: Yes. And congratulations to all of you. It was superb.

question: Oh, by the way, give him this. This is his share. That should cheer him up, eh?
answer: Yes, indeed. Goodnight to you all now. It was perfection - truly!

question: Yes, indeed. Goodnight to you all now. It was perfection - truly!
answer: What happened?

question: He said to give you this. And if you finish the work by tomorrow night, he will pay you another hundred ducats.
answer: Another? But that's too soon! Tomorrow night? It's impossible! Did he say a hundred?

question: Yes. Can I - could I help you, in any way?
answer: Would you? Actually, you could.

question: My dear friend, it would be my greatest pleasure.
answer: But you'd have to swear not to tell a soul. I'm not allowed.

question: Of course.
answer: You know, it's all here in my head. It's just ready to be set down. But when I'm dizzy like this my eyes won't focus. I can't write.

question: Then, let us try together. I'd regard it as such an honour. Tell me, what is this work?
answer: A Mass. A Mass for the Dead.

question: What is it?
answer: I want to go!

question: Where?
answer: I want to go back to Vienna.

question: Now?
answer: Yes!

question: Why?
answer: I feel wrong. I feel wrong being here.

question: Where did I stop?
answer: The end of the Recordare - Statuens in parte dextra.

question: So now the Confutatis. Confutatis Maledictis. When the wicked are confounded. Flammis acribus addictis. How would you translate that?
answer: Consigned to flames of woe.

question: Do you believe in it?
answer: What?

question: A fire which never dies. Burning one forever?
answer: Oh, yes.

question: Strange!
answer: Come. Let's begin. Confutatis Maledictis.

question: We ended in F Major?
answer: Yes.

question: So now - A minor. Suddenly. The Fire.
answer: What time?

question: Common time. Start with the voices. Basses first. Second beat of the first measure -
answer: Yes.

question: Third measure, second beat starting on E. Flam-mis a-cri-bus ad-dic-tis. And fourth measure, fourth beat - D. Ma-le-dic-tis, flam-mis a-cri-bus ad- dic-tis. Do you have that?
answer: I think so.

question: Sing it back. Good. Now the tenors. Fourth beat of the first measure - C. Con-fu-ta-tis. Second measure, fourth beat on D. Ma-le-dic-tis. All right?
answer: Yes.

question: Fourth measure, second beat - F. Flam-mis a-cri-bus ad-dic-tis, flam- mis a-cri-bus ad-dic-tis. Now the orchestra. Second bassoon and bass trombone with the basses. Identical notes and rhythm. The first bassoon and tenor trombone -
answer: Please! Just one moment.

question: It couldn't be simpler.
answer: First bassoon and tenor trombone - what?

question: With the tenors.
answer: Also identical?

question: Exactly. The instruments to go with the voices. Trumpets and timpani, tonic and dominant.
answer: And that's all?

question: Oh no. Now for the Fire. Strings in unison - ostinato on all - like this. Second measure on B. Do you have me?
answer: I think so.

question: Show me. Good, good - yes! Put it down. And the next measures exactly the same, rising and rising - C to D to E, up to the dominant chord. Do you see?
answer: That's wonderful!

question: Yes, yes - go on. The Voca Me. Suddenly sotto voce. Write that down C Major. Sopranos and altos in thirds. Altos on C. Sopranos above. Vo-ca, vo-ca me, vo-ca me cum be-ne- dic-tis.
answer: Sopranos up to F on the second 'Voca'?

question: Yes, and on 'dictis'.
answer: Yes!

question: And underneath, just violins - arpeggio. The descending scale in eighth notes, and then back suddenly to the fire again. And that's it. Do you have it?
answer: You go fast!

question: Do you have it?
answer: Yes.

question: Then let me hear it. All of it. The whole thing from the beginning - now! Do you want to rest a bit?
answer: Oh no. I'm not tired at all.

question: We'll stop for just a moment. Then we'll do the Lacrimosa.
answer: I can keep going, I assure you. Shall we try?

question: Would you stay with me while I sleep a little?
answer: I'm not leaving you.

question: I am so ashamed.
answer: What for?

question: What are you doing here?
answer: Your husband is ill, ma'am. He took sick. I brought him home.

question: Why you?
answer: I was at hand.

question: Well, thank you very much. You can go now.
answer: He needs me, ma'am.

question: No, he doesn't. And I don't want you here. Just go, please.
answer: He asked me to stay.

question: And I'm asking you - Wolfi, I'm back. I'm still very angry with you, but I missed you so much. I'll never leave you again. If you'll just try a little harder to be nice to me. And I'll try to do better, too. We must. We must! This was just silly and stupid. What is this? Oh no, not this. Not this, Wolfi! You're not to work on this ever again! I've decided. This is not his handwriting.
answer: No. I was assisting him. He asked me.

question: He's not going to work on this anymore. It is making him ill. Please. Please. Thank you.
answer: But - but - but -

question: Good night. I regret we have no servants to show you out, Herr Salieri. Respect my wish and go.
answer: Madame, I will respect his. He asked me to stay here.
